Comments and notes to 漢書 for translation .

p.seg: As Yan Shigu 顏師古 (581–645) comments, <luo> 臝 means "without scales, shell, pelage or feathers" 無鱗甲毛羽 (<Han shu>, 27BA.1405, n. 3). Ban Gu uses the alternative spelling 裸.
生 (birth) and 眚 (ill omen) form a graphic and phonetic pun (paronomasia), since both probably belonged to the same rhyme group Geng 耕 in Han times.

Bringing 妖 and 夭 together is a case of paronomasia. Cf. Xu Shen's 許慎 (1st cent. CE–after 120) <Shuowen jiezi> 說文解字 (ca. 100 CE): Xu Shen's definition of <nie> (written 蠥) was visibly influenced by the same material as that used by Ban Gu, if not directly by Ban Gu’s monograph itself: "One speaks of 'deviance' for strangeness in garments, in songs and rhyme, and in plants; of 'anomaly' for strangeness in wild beasts and legged animals [such as] locust" 衣服歌謠艸木之怪謂之䄏；禽獸蟲蝗之怪謂之蠥 (<Shuowen jiezi>, 283a). [禽獸 includes all non-domestic birds and quadrupeds, hence my "wild beasts".] Dictionaries usually consider Xu Shen's spelling (䄏 and 蠥) and Ban Gu’s (妖 and 孽) to be equivalent.
臨莅 is an allusion to a newly enthroned sovereign's accession to power.
